Award.AwardTitle: Computational Investigation of the Chemical Modification of Polymers and Organic Thin Films by Particle Deposition
Award.AbstractNarration:
Susan Sinnott of the University of Florida is supported by an award from the Theoretical and Computational Chemistry program for the development of computational methods for the simulation of particle-surface reactions in polymers and organic thin films. The work is identifying the atomic-level processes involved in the chemical modification of polymers by polyatomic ions and radicals and is investigating the selective modification of oligomers with optoelectronic properties through the deposition of ions and radicals at hyperthermal incident energies.

Particle-surface deposition occurs over a wide range of incident energies and is used for a variety of industrially vital applications, including thin-film growth, doping, sputtering, etching, chemical modification and creation of new interfacial stuctures. The work is having a broader impact through the development of computational tools that will be freely disseminated through the PI's website and via the nanoHUB (www.nanohub.org), an NSF-supported cyberinfrastructure. It is having a further broader impact through the training and mentoring of students, including several undergraduates, some of whom are members of under-represented minority groups. Some of the students involved are working with Nedialka Iordanova through a subaward to Georgia Southwestern State University.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project is made up of two related technical tasks that have provided important insights into different aspects of the physics and chemistry of polymer surface chemistry. In the first task, quantum mechanical and atomic-scale computer simulation methods were used to identify the chemical processes involved in the modification of the surfaces of polymers and organic molecules.  In particular, their modification through the deposition of single atoms or ions composed of more than one atom with kinetic energies in the range of 10-100 eV were considered. This is important because polymer surface modification by atoms and ions generated by plasmas are used to prepare biomedical implants and electronic devices, both of which are widely used by society at large. In the second task, new computational methods were developed to improve our ability to carry out these simulations and more realistically predict surface chemistry and resulting material properties.  

This project was collaborative between Prof. Susan Sinnott at the University of Florida (UF) and Prof. Nedialka Iordanova of Georgia Southwestern State University (GSW). Several graduate students (at UF), undergraduate students (at UF and GSW), and high school students (at UF) worked on this research. As a result, they were training in advanced material modeling methods and data analysis.


Last Modified: 08/01/2013
Modified by: Susan B Sinnott
